Baroque_and_Rococo.description: Apollo and Daphne is a life-size Baroque marble sculpture by Gian Lorenzo Bernini, depicting the climactic moment from Ovid's Metamorphoses when the nymph Daphne is transformed into a laurel tree to escape the god Apollo's pursuit.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A masterpiece of Baroque sculpture, renowned for its dynamic composition, technical virtuosity, and dramatic depiction of transformation, exemplifying Bernini's ability to convey intense emotion and movement in marble.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp is a 1632 oil painting on canvas by Rembrandt, depicting Dr. Tulp demonstrating the musculature of the arm to members of the Amsterdam Guild of Surgeons. The work is celebrated for its dramatic composition, masterful use of light and shadow, and psychological depth.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: This painting is considered one of Rembrandt's early masterpieces and a landmark in group portraiture, notable for its innovative composition and vivid realism. It reflects the scientific spirit of the Dutch Golden Age and Rembrandt's skill in capturing character and narrative.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Pilgrimage to Cythera
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: Pilgrimage to Cythera (also known as The Embarkation for Cythera) is a celebrated painting by French artist Jean-Antoine Watteau, depicting elegantly dressed couples departing for or returning from the mythical island of Cythera, the birthplace of Venus, symbolizing love and pleasure.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A masterpiece of the Rococo era, this painting established Watteau's reputation and introduced the genre of fête galante, capturing the spirit of aristocratic leisure and romantic longing.

1800s.title: The Third of May 1808
1800s.description: The Third of May 1808, also known in Spanish as El tres de mayo de 1808 en Madrid or Los fusilamientos de la montaña del Príncipe Pío, is a painting completed in 1814 by Spanish artist Francisco Goya. The work commemorates the Spanish resistance to Napoleon's armies during the occupation of Madrid in 1808, at the beginning of the Peninsular War. It depicts the execution of Spanish rebels by French soldiers and is renowned for its emotional intensity and innovative composition. The painting, along with its companion piece The Second of May 1808, was commissioned by the provisional government of Spain after the expulsion of the French and the restoration of King Ferdinand VII.
1800s.significance: A landmark of Romantic art, The Third of May 1808 is celebrated for its powerful depiction of the horrors of war and its influence on later artists. It is considered one of the first modern paintings to portray war from the perspective of the victims, emphasizing human suffering and protest against violence.

1800s.title: Liberty Leading the People
1800s.description: Liberty Leading the People is a monumental Romantic painting by Eugène Delacroix commemorating the July Revolution of 1830 in France. The central allegorical figure, Liberty, personified as Marianne, leads a diverse group of revolutionaries over a barricade and the bodies of the fallen, holding the tricolor flag and a musket. The work is celebrated for its dynamic composition, emotional intensity, and political symbolism, encapsulating the spirit of revolution and the fight for freedom.
1800s.significance: A defining image of the Romantic era and a powerful symbol of liberty and revolution, this painting has become an enduring emblem of the French Republic and the universal struggle for freedom.

1800s.title: The Gleaners
1800s.description: The Gleaners is an oil painting by Jean-François Millet completed in 1857. It depicts three peasant women gleaning a field of stray grains of wheat after the harvest, highlighting the dignity and hardship of rural laborers.
1800s.significance: A landmark of Realist painting, 'The Gleaners' is celebrated for its sympathetic portrayal of rural poverty and its social commentary on class and labor in 19th-century France.

1800s.title: Olympia
1800s.description: Olympia is a painting by French artist Édouard Manet depicting a nude woman reclining on a bed, attended by a maid. The work shocked audiences when first exhibited due to its frank portrayal of a nude courtesan and its modern, confrontational style.
1800s.significance: A pivotal work in the transition from Realism to Impressionism, 'Olympia' challenged academic conventions and social norms, and is considered a landmark in the history of modern art.

1800s.title: Impression, Sunrise
1800s.description: Impression, Sunrise is an 1872 painting by Claude Monet, first exhibited at the 1874 exhibition that would become known as the first Impressionist exhibition in Paris. The painting depicts the port of Le Havre at sunrise and is credited with inspiring the name of the Impressionist movement.
1800s.significance: This painting gave the Impressionist movement its name and is considered a seminal work in the development of modern art, exemplifying Monet's innovative approach to capturing light, atmosphere, and fleeting moments.

1800s.title: Starry Night Over the Rhône
1800s.description: Starry Night Over the Rhône is one of Vincent van Gogh's celebrated nocturne paintings, depicting a star-filled sky reflected in the waters of the Rhône River in Arles, France. Painted outdoors at night, the work captures the interplay of artificial gas lighting along the riverbank and the natural brilliance of the stars, exemplifying van Gogh's fascination with the night and his innovative use of color and brushwork.
1800s.significance: This painting is significant for its pioneering depiction of nocturnal light, its expressive use of color, and its role in van Gogh's exploration of the emotional and symbolic potential of the night sky. It is a key work in the development of modern art and a precursor to his later masterpiece, The Starry Night.

1800s.title: The Starry Night
1800s.description: The Starry Night is an oil-on-canvas painting by Dutch Post-Impressionist artist Vincent van Gogh, created in June 1889. It depicts a swirling night sky over a quiet town, as seen from the window of his asylum room at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, with imaginative elements such as the cypress tree and a stylized village. The painting is celebrated for its expressive brushwork, vivid colors, and emotional intensity.
1800s.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York City, USA
1800s.significance: Regarded as one of the most iconic and influential paintings in Western art, The Starry Night exemplifies van Gogh's innovative use of color and brushwork, and has become a symbol of modern art's expressive potential.

1800s.title: Bal du moulin de la Galette
1800s.description: Bal du moulin de la Galette is a celebrated Impressionist painting by Pierre-Auguste Renoir, depicting a lively outdoor scene of working-class Parisians dancing and socializing at the Moulin de la Galette in Montmartre, Paris.
1800s.significance: One of the masterpieces of Impressionism, this painting captures the vibrant social life of late 19th-century Paris with luminous color, lively brushwork, and a sense of fleeting movement. It is renowned for its depiction of light and atmosphere, as well as its joyful, convivial subject matter.

1800s.title: The Thinker
1800s.description: The Thinker is a bronze sculpture by Auguste Rodin depicting a nude male figure of heroic size, seated on a rock with his chin resting on one hand as though deep in thought. Originally conceived as part of Rodin's monumental work 'The Gates of Hell', the figure has become an independent icon of intellectual activity and contemplation, symbolizing philosophy and the creative mind.
1800s.dimensions: Height: 186 cm (73 in); Width: 98 cm (38.5 in); Depth: 145 cm (57 in) [original monumental version]
1800s.significance: One of the most recognizable sculptures in the world, 'The Thinker' is celebrated for its expressive realism and psychological depth, embodying the spirit of modern sculpture and symbolizing human contemplation.

1800s.title: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte
1800s.description: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte is Georges Seurat's most celebrated painting, created between 1884 and 1886. This monumental work exemplifies the pointillist technique, in which small, distinct dots of color are applied in patterns to form an image. The scene depicts Parisians relaxing in a suburban park on the banks of the River Seine, capturing the leisure activities of late 19th-century society. The painting is a cornerstone of the Neo-Impressionist movement.
1800s.current_location: Art Institute of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois, USA
1800s.significance: A foundational work of Neo-Impressionism, this painting introduced the revolutionary technique of pointillism and profoundly influenced the direction of modern art. Its innovative approach to color and composition marks a pivotal moment in the transition from Impressionism to modernism.

1900_1945.title: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon
1900_1945.description: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon is a groundbreaking large oil painting by Spanish artist Pablo Picasso, completed in 1907. The work depicts five nude female figures in a brothel on Carrer d'Avinyó in Barcelona, rendered with angular, fractured forms and mask-like faces. The painting marks a radical break from traditional composition and perspective, incorporating influences from Iberian sculpture and African masks. It is widely considered a pivotal work in the development of Cubism and modern art.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
1900_1945.significance: Regarded as one of the most influential paintings of the 20th century, 'Les Demoiselles d'Avignon' shattered conventional representation and paved the way for Cubism, revolutionizing modern art with its radical approach to form and perspective.

1900_1945.title: The Kiss
1900_1945.description: The Kiss is an iconic painting by Austrian Symbolist painter Gustav Klimt, depicting a couple locked in an intimate embrace, their bodies entwined in elaborate, gilded robes against a shimmering gold background.
1900_1945.medium: Oil and gold leaf on canvas
1900_1945.significance: Considered Klimt's masterpiece and a quintessential example of early 20th-century Symbolism and Art Nouveau, 'The Kiss' is celebrated for its sensual imagery, decorative gold leaf, and exploration of love and intimacy.

1900_1945.title: Composition VII
1900_1945.description: Composition VII is a monumental abstract oil painting created by Wassily Kandinsky in 1913. Widely regarded as one of his masterpieces, the work is a swirling, energetic composition that synthesizes themes of Resurrection, Judgment Day, the Flood, and the Garden of Eden. It exemplifies Kandinsky's pioneering role in the development of abstract art and his theories on the spiritual power of color and form.
1900_1945.significance: Considered one of the most important works of early abstract art, 'Composition VII' is a culmination of Kandinsky's exploration of non-representational painting and his theories on the emotional and spiritual resonance of color and form. It marks a turning point in modern art and influenced generations of abstract artists.

1900_1945.title: Fountain
1900_1945.description: Fountain is a readymade sculpture by Marcel Duchamp consisting of a porcelain urinal signed 'R. Mutt'. Submitted to the 1917 Society of Independent Artists exhibition in New York, it challenged traditional notions of art by presenting an ordinary object as an artwork.
1900_1945.current_location: Replica: Philadelphia Museum of Art, Philadelphia, USA (original lost)
1900_1945.dimensions: 36 cm × 48 cm × 61 cm (14 in × 19 in × 24 in)
1900_1945.significance: A landmark of 20th-century art, 'Fountain' redefined the boundaries of art by introducing the concept of the 'readymade' and questioning the role of the artist and the art institution.

1900_1945.title: Guernica
1900_1945.description: Guernica is a monumental black-and-white oil painting by Pablo Picasso, created in response to the bombing of the Basque town of Guernica during the Spanish Civil War. The work powerfully depicts the tragedies of war and the suffering it inflicts upon individuals, particularly innocent civilians.
1900_1945.significance: Guernica is one of the most famous anti-war paintings in history, symbolizing the horrors of war and the suffering of innocent people. It has become an enduring symbol of peace and a powerful political statement.

1900_1945.title: The Persistence of Memory
1900_1945.description: The Persistence of Memory is a 1931 painting by Spanish artist Salvador Dalí and is one of the most iconic works of Surrealism. The painting features melting pocket watches draped over a dreamlike landscape, evoking themes of time, memory, and the subconscious. Its enigmatic imagery and technical precision have made it a symbol of Surrealist art and a frequent reference in popular culture.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York City, USA
1900_1945.significance: A quintessential work of Surrealism, 'The Persistence of Memory' is celebrated for its dreamlike imagery and exploration of the fluidity of time, and has become one of the most recognizable and influential paintings of the 20th century.

1900_1945.title: Broadway Boogie Woogie
1900_1945.description: Broadway Boogie Woogie is an abstract oil painting by Piet Mondrian, completed shortly after his move to New York City. The work reflects the city's grid structure and the rhythm of boogie-woogie music, using a vibrant arrangement of colored squares and rectangles.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
1900_1945.significance: Considered one of Mondrian's masterpieces, this painting marks the culmination of his abstract style and his response to the energy of New York. It is celebrated for its innovative use of color, grid structure, and its synthesis of visual art and music.

1900_1945.title: The Red Studio
1900_1945.description: The Red Studio is an oil on canvas painting by French artist Henri Matisse, completed in 1911. The work depicts the artist’s studio in Issy-les-Moulineaux, filled with his own paintings, sculptures, and furniture, all unified by a vibrant red color that flattens the perspective and blurs the boundaries between objects and space.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
1900_1945.significance: A landmark of modern art, The Red Studio is celebrated for its radical use of color, spatial ambiguity, and its influence on abstraction. It exemplifies Matisse’s innovative approach to composition and color, and is considered a key work in the development of 20th-century painting.

1900_1945.title: Black Square
1900_1945.description: Black Square is a 1915 oil on canvas painting by Russian avant-garde artist Kazimir Malevich. It is considered the first and most iconic work of Suprematism, a movement focused on basic geometric forms and pure artistic feeling. Malevich created several versions of the painting, with the original debuting at the 0.10 Exhibition in Petrograd.
1900_1945.significance: Regarded as a groundbreaking work in abstract art, Black Square marked the birth of Suprematism and represented a radical break from representational painting, influencing the development of modern art in the 20th century.

1900_1945.title: American Gothic
1900_1945.description: American Gothic is a 1930 oil painting on beaverboard by the American Regionalist artist Grant Wood. It depicts a stern-faced farmer holding a pitchfork beside a woman, often interpreted as his daughter, standing in front of a Carpenter Gothic-style house in rural Iowa. The painting has become an iconic image of American art, symbolizing rural values and the American Midwest.
1900_1945.current_location: Art Institute of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois, USA
1900_1945.significance: One of the most recognizable paintings in American art, 'American Gothic' is celebrated for its depiction of rural American life and its influence on popular culture. It is a key work of the Regionalist movement and has been widely parodied and referenced.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Number 1A
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Number 1A is a large-scale abstract expressionist painting by Jackson Pollock, exemplifying his signature drip technique and energetic, gestural style.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Oil and enamel paint on canvas
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark of Abstract Expressionism, Number 1A demonstrates Pollock's innovative drip painting technique and his move toward all-over composition, influencing generations of artists.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Campbell's Soup Cans
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Campbell's Soup Cans is a series of 32 paintings produced by American artist Andy Warhol. Each canvas depicts a different variety of Campbell's soup, rendered in a style that mimics commercial printing. The series is a landmark of the Pop Art movement, challenging traditional distinctions between fine art and mass-produced imagery.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: The Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Each canvas: 51 cm × 41 cm (20 in × 16 in)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A seminal work of Pop Art, 'Campbell's Soup Cans' redefined the boundaries of art by elevating everyday commercial imagery to the status of fine art and critiquing consumer culture.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Blue Poles
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Blue Poles, also known as Number 11, 1952, is a landmark abstract expressionist painting by American artist Jackson Pollock. The work is renowned for its dynamic composition, featuring bold blue vertical lines over a complex web of dripped and splattered paint. Its acquisition by the National Gallery of Australia in 1973 was highly controversial and marked a turning point in the recognition of modern American art internationally.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Enamel and aluminum paint with glass on canvas
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Considered one of Pollock's masterpieces and a key example of Abstract Expressionism, 'Blue Poles' is notable for its scale, innovative technique, and its role in establishing the international reputation of postwar American art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Untitled (Portrait of Ross in L.A.)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: "Untitled" (Portrait of Ross in L.A.) is a conceptual installation by Cuban-American artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres. The work consists of a pile of individually wrapped candies, ideally weighing 175 pounds (79 kg), which visitors are invited to take and consume. The diminishing pile alludes to the gradual loss of Gonzalez-Torres's partner, Ross Laycock, to AIDS, and the replenishment of the pile by museum staff symbolizes care and remembrance. The work is both participatory and ephemeral, challenging traditional notions of permanence in art.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Art Institute of Chicago, Chicago, United States
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Ideal weight: 175 lb (79 kg); dimensions variable
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark of participatory and conceptual art, the work is a poignant meditation on love, loss, and the AIDS crisis, inviting viewers to engage physically and emotionally with the memory of the artist's partner.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living is a seminal work by Damien Hirst, consisting of a tiger shark preserved in formaldehyde within a large glass vitrine. Commissioned by art collector Charles Saatchi, the piece confronts viewers with the reality of death and the boundaries between art and life.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, USA (on loan from the Steven A. Cohen collection)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Tiger shark, glass, steel, 5% formaldehyde solution
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark of contemporary art, this work epitomizes the shock tactics and conceptual approach of the Young British Artists, provoking debate about mortality, preservation, and the definition of art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Balloon Dog
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Balloon Dog is a series of monumental sculptures by American artist Jeff Koons, created as part of his 'Celebration' series. The sculptures resemble twisted balloon animals, rendered in highly polished stainless steel with transparent color coatings. Five unique versions exist, each in a different color: blue, magenta, yellow, orange, and red.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Various (individual pieces in private collections and museums; Balloon Dog (Orange) was sold at Christie's, New York; Balloon Dog (Blue) at The Broad, Los Angeles)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Mirror-polished stainless steel with transparent color coating
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Balloon Dog is one of Jeff Koons's most iconic works, exemplifying his use of industrial materials and playful, familiar forms to challenge notions of high and low art. The sculptures have become symbols of contemporary art's engagement with consumer culture and have achieved record-breaking auction prices.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: The Dinner Party
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Dinner Party is a landmark installation artwork by American feminist artist Judy Chicago. The work consists of a large, triangular table with 39 elaborate place settings, each commemorating an important woman from history or mythology. The settings include intricately decorated ceramic plates and embroidered runners, with the names of 999 additional women inscribed on the floor below. The piece is a celebration of women's achievements and a critique of their historical marginalization.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Brooklyn Museum, Brooklyn, New York, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Overall: 1463 cm × 1463 cm × 76.2 cm (48 ft × 48 ft × 30 in)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Widely regarded as a milestone of feminist art, 'The Dinner Party' brought attention to the achievements of women throughout history and challenged the male-dominated art historical canon. Its collaborative creation and monumental scale helped redefine the possibilities of installation art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Spiral Jetty
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Spiral Jetty is a monumental earthwork and iconic piece of land art constructed by American artist Robert Smithson in April 1970. Built on the northeastern shore of the Great Salt Lake near Rozel Point in Utah, the work consists of a 1,500-foot-long (460 m), 15-foot-wide (4.6 m) counterclockwise spiral made from mud, salt crystals, basalt rocks, and earth. The sculpture interacts with the changing water levels and salinity of the lake, often submerging and re-emerging over time. Smithson documented the construction in a 32-minute color film, also titled Spiral Jetty.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Rozel Point, Great Salt Lake, Utah, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.creation_location: Rozel Point, Great Salt Lake, Utah, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Basalt rock, earth, salt crystals, mud
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: 460 m (1,500 ft) long; 4.6 m (15 ft) wide
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark of the Land Art movement, Spiral Jetty is celebrated for its integration of art and landscape, its engagement with entropy and natural processes, and its influence on environmental and conceptual art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Girl with Balloon
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Girl with Balloon is a series of stencil murals created by the anonymous street artist Banksy, first appearing in London in 2002. The image depicts a young girl reaching out toward a red, heart-shaped balloon being carried away by the wind. Originally painted on the walls under Waterloo Bridge and in Shoreditch, the murals have become one of Banksy's most iconic images and have been reproduced in prints and other media.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Spray paint and stencil on wall
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Variable (site-specific mural); original Shoreditch mural approx. 60 cm × 90 cm (24 in × 35 in)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: One of the most recognizable works of contemporary street art, 'Girl with Balloon' has become a symbol of hope and lost innocence. Its imagery and message have been widely reproduced and referenced in popular culture. The work also gained notoriety when a print version partially shredded itself at auction in 2018.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: The Weather Project
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Weather Project is a large-scale installation by Icelandic–Danish artist Olafur Eliasson, which filled the Turbine Hall of Tate Modern in London. The installation simulated the experience of a vast indoor sun and mist-filled atmosphere, using light, mirrors, and haze to immerse visitors in an artificial environment that encouraged reflection on nature and perception.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Monofrequency lights, haze machines, mirrors, aluminum, scaffolding
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Approximately 26.7 m × 22.3 m × 155.4 m (88 ft × 73 ft × 510 ft) (entire Turbine Hall)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark in immersive installation art, The Weather Project transformed the museum experience and engaged the public in questions about perception, environment, and collective experience. It is considered one of the most influential works of early 21st-century art.
